results.name: Number of ways to write n as the sum u+v+w of three palindromes (from A002113) with 0 <= u <= v <= w.
comment: It is known that a(n) > 0 for every n, i.e., every number can be written as the sum of 3 palindromes.

The graph has a kind of self-similarity: looking at the first 100 values, there is a Gaussian-shaped peak centered at the first local maximum a(15) = 18. Looking at the first 10000 values, one sees just one Gaussian-shaped peak centered around the record and local maximum a(1453) = 766, but to both sides of this value there are smaller peaks, roughly at distances which are multiples of 10. In the range [1..10^6], one sees a Gaussian-shaped peak centered around the record a(164445) = 57714. In the range [1..3*10^7], there is a similar peak of height ~ 4.3*10^6 at 1.65*10^7, with smaller neighbor peaks at distances which are multiples of 10^6, etc. - _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 09 2018

formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..3} A319453(n,k). - _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 19 2018
example: a(28) = 6 since 28 can be expressed in 6 ways as the sum of 3 palindromes, namely, 28 = 0+6+22 = 1+5+22 = 2+4+22 = 3+3+22 = 6+11+11 = 8+9+11.
maple: if z >= y and isA002113(z) then
mathematica: pal=Select[Range[0, 1000], (d = IntegerDigits@ #; d == Reverse@ d)&]; a[n_] := Length@ IntegerPartitions[n, {3}, pal]; a /@ Range[0, 1000]
program: (PARI) A261132(n)=n||return(1); my(c=0, i=inv_A002113(n)); A2113[i] > n && i--; until( A2113[i--]*3 < n, j = inv_A002113(D = n-A2113[i]); if( j>i, j=i, A2113[j] > D && j--); while( j >= k = inv_A002113(D - A2113[j]), A2113[k] == D - A2113[j] && c++; j--||break));c \\ For efficiency, this uses an array A2113 precomputed at least up to n. - _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 10 2018
